Author: tdavis
Content:
We've been using BackType in Beta for a while now and it has been an incredibly useful service. They're already a good way to keep up on what people are saying about your business (much like Google Groups) and as they add more blogs to the fold it will only increase the usefulness.

Great job guys.

Author: Goladus
Content:
why not companies funded by YC?

Because the standard of 'notability' is bogus when applied to something of the supposed scope of wikipedia. It's impossible to apply it with any reasonable consistency, and it always boils down to a few biased opinions, which is why the topic of notability deletions is so sensitive.

Author: konsl
Content: FYI Everyone can add their Hacker News comments to their profiles too -- add http://news.ycombinator.com/user?id=YOUR_USERNAME to the list of websites on your account page. Alternatively, you could just do a people search for your username and claim it from there.

Author: sabat
Content: Get a new business model. Trying to 'sell' software is like trying to hug water.

Author: JeremyChase
Content:
Ok, my example isn't the best.

The reason it came to mind is that an xterm window is a perfect example of horrid "UI" that functions beautifully. The interface is often unfriendly with unexpected results, but you can get a lot done in a short amount of time.

Jer

Author: Timothee
Content:
In fact, the "twice as fast" was removed from the ads in Canada and replaced by something like "pretty fast". Also absent from Apple Canada website (http://www.apple.com/ca/)

The "half the price" part is indeed a very annoying marketing trick.

Author: hugh
Content:
It's trivially easy for two smart guys in a garage to create a competitor.

It's difficult to persuade hundreds of thousands of people outside said garage to write the actual content.

Author: unexpected
Content: yea, I seriously miss insider. It was pretty good, especially for the NBA draft. I miss all those mocks :( As an aside, ESPN basically has the lamest security ever. So we were splitting an insider subscription amongst 4 people. The $12 a year became $3. Woohoo!

Author: zandorg
Content:
I remember a casino where the communication between player and server was done using SSL. I compiled a custom OpenSSL DLL and was able to intercept the roulette commands!

Unfortunately whether it was a winning bet was done on the server, and the communication was just sending the bet to the server, and the other way, the result to the player.

Author: mattmaroon
Content: Paypal's merchant services still have a montly fee.

Author: danielha
Title: Disqus (YC 07) is hiring: Back-end, Front-end Engineers
Content:
Disqus is a dedicated commenting service used by thousands of websites including blogs, newspapers, and web applications. Our team is small, focused, and passionate about creating products that people love to use. We are building a company with the purpose of making a great impact on how the web is used and perceived.

We're actively looking to hire smart people to join our team. Current positions include: Back-end Engineer, Front-end Engineer, Software Developer Intern, Customer/Community Support

--

Back-end Engineer

  + Very strong with at least one programming language, preferably Python
  + Familiar with JavaScript
  + Good knowledge of several other programming languages, such as Perl, is a plus
  + Other pluses include: Django, PHP, PostgreSQL, years of development experience
Front-end Engineer

  + Very strong with JavaScript
  + Adept with web standards and cross-browser development
  + Good sense of user experience and interfaces
  + XHTML, CSS
  + Pluses: website design

  ***

  Please send your resume or background description (education, experience), and code examples to:  jobs@disqus.com

  ***
Disqus participated in Y Combinator in 2007 and has investment from Union Square Ventures.

More about Disqus: http://disqus.com/docs/company

More open positions on the job page: http://disqus.com/docs/jobs

Author: mattmaroon
Content: Is ESPN's insider content that much better than what you get for free elsewhere? If so, that's really saying a lot, since the bar for sports content has risen faster than the price of gas over the last few years.

Author: zenspider
Content:
"The most obvious example that comes to mind is an xterm window. Even on OSX any programmer will spend 2/3 of their time looking at text."

Isn't that an example of _good_ UI? Much like Pages does a good job of giving you a blank sheet of paper and not much else (initially), Terminal.app does a good job of giving you a command line and not much else (ever).

Author: mattmaroon
Content: Interesting. Those are free on ESPN now. And, of course, Draftmix :)

Author: JeremyChase
Content:
UI is extremely important, but this article is wrong to say that without it your product is doomed to fail.

The most obvious example that comes to mind is an xterm window. Even on OSX any programmer will spend 2/3 of their time looking at text.

Jer
